wikipedia_page.main: William Blake (31 January 1774 – 1852) was an English classical economist who contributed to the early theory of purchasing power parity.

response: The debate developed over the economic concept of a general glut, and the possibility of failure of Say's Law. Malthus laid importance on economic development and the persistence of disequilibrium.Sowell, pp. 193–4. The context was the post-war depression; Malthus had a supporter in William Blake, in denying that capital accumulation (saving) was always good in such circumstances, and John Stuart Mill attacked Blake on the fringes of the debate.
* William Blake (1774–1852), President of the Geological Society of London 1815–1816

*William Blake (1774–1852), an economist, leased St John's Lodge, Welwyn, with a park of 130 acres, in 1819 and bought it in 1824, changing the name to Danesbury.The National Archives, Estate and family papers of the Blake family of Danesbury, Welwyn, 1776–1924. He was High Sheriff of Hertfordshire in 1836.
*William Blake (1774–1852), English classical economist who contributed to the early theory of purchasing power parity
William Blake (1757–1827) was an English poet, visionary, painter, and printmaker.
William Blake may also refer to:
* William Blake (economist) (1774–1852), English writer on monetary policy and government expenditure
* William Blake (outlaw) (1859–1895), outlaw of the Old West, and member of the Wild Bunch gang
* William Blake, a character in Dead Man
* The William Blakes, a Danish pop rock band
* William Blake Herron, film screenwriter, director and actor
* William Blake Richmond (1842–1921), English painter and decorator
